markdownRemark.excerpt:
Bagels

VEG

Some people say it’s the water that makes New York’s bagels so gosh darn amazing. Maybe. But NYC is home to some of the world’s finest bagels and makes for one heck of a breakfast.

Can eat in Breakfast

Cheesecake

VEG

New York cheesecake is known for its creamy, satiny texture. It's rich, dense and tall with a flat top – exactly how I like my cheesecake. It's made with cream cheese, eggs, egg yolks and heavy cream or sour cream, to add richness and smooth consistency.

Can eat in Dessert

Pizza

VEG Non-VEG

Pizza in New York City is a must. New York Pizza is the best pizza in the United States as pizza came to the United States starting in NYC. Really. The first pizzeria in the United States of America was opened in 1905 by an Italian immigrant from Naples in New York City.

Can eat in Lunch · Dinner

Corned Beef

No-Veg

Although the exact beginnings of corned beef are unknown, it most likely came about when people began preserving meat through salt-curing. Evidence of its legacy is apparent in numerous cultures, including ancient Europe and the Middle East.

Can eat in Lunch · Dinner

Hot Dog

Veg

In the US, the term "hot dog" refers to both the sausage by itself and the combination of sausage and bun. Many nicknames applying to either have emerged over the years, including frankfurter, frank, wiener, weenie, coney, and red hot. Annually, Americans consume 20 billion hot dogs.

Can eat in Breakfast · Lunch · Snacks

frontmatter.title: New York
frontmatter.description: All of the dollar slices, bodega delicacies, and Michelin-starred kitchens that define New York's legendary culinary scene. Here's what you must try...
